title: Suspicious Encoded PowerShell Command Execution
description: Multiple detections of encoded PowerShell usage within the last 12 hours. Encoded commands are commonly used by attackers to obfuscate malicious scripts and evade detection. These detections exclude known benign scripts (gc_worker, ACL, Nessus), increasing confidence that the activity is not routine admin scripting.

mitre.description: Adversaries may abuse PowerShell commands and scripts for execution of malicious payloads, evasion, or downloading further stagers.

log_lines: 2025-12-04 19:29:14.657677+00:00,SL_Encoded PowerShell Command Detection,SL_Encoded PowerShell Command Detection,High,"Detects use of PowerShell with -enc/-encodedcommand, excluding known benign scripts (gc_worker, ACL, Nessus).",ASI Scheduled Alerts

2025-12-04 18:29:17.017697+00:00,SL_Encoded PowerShell Command Detection,SL_Encoded PowerShell Command Detection,High,"Detects use of PowerShell with -enc/-encodedcommand, excluding known benign scripts (gc_worker, ACL, Nessus).",ASI Scheduled Alerts

2025-12-04 17:29:15.888668+00:00,SL_Encoded PowerShell Command Detection,SL_Encoded PowerShell Command Detection,High,"Detects use of PowerShell with -enc/-encodedcommand, excluding known benign scripts (gc_worker, ACL, Nessus).",ASI Scheduled Alerts
notes: Correlate process start events and command lines for decoded command details. Review associated user accounts and endpoints for lateral movement or privilege escalation.

title: Suspicious Network Beaconing from CLI Utilities on Linux
description: Multiple alerts for suspicious network beaconing using command-line utilities (curl, wget, dhpcd, etc.), indicative of possible command-and-control (C2) activity, on Linux systems. Alerts are tuned for low false positives and prioritize non-standard, high-frequency, or port-diverse outbound connections not related to known update services.

mitre.description: Adversaries may communicate using web protocols via tools like curl/wget for C2 or data exfiltration.

log_lines: 2025-12-04 18:40:28.638622+00:00,"SL[LINUX] Suspicious Network Beaconing from CLI Utilities (curl, wget, dhpcd, etc.)","SL[LINUX] Suspicious Network Beaconing from CLI Utilities (curl, wget, dhpcd, etc.)",High,"Detects potential command-and-control (C2) activity originating from known command-line tools such as curl, wget, dhpcd, and custom binaries. The rule calculates a behavior score based on connection count and port usage diversity. Legitimate update services and known benign calls are excluded via pattern matching.

2025-12-04 17:40:26.793445+00:00,"SL[LINUX] Suspicious Network Beaconing from CLI Utilities (curl, wget, dhpcd, etc.)","SL[LINUX] Suspicious Network Beaconing from CLI Utilities (curl, wget, dhpcd, etc.)",High,"Detects potential command-and-control (C2) activity originating from known command-line tools such as curl, wget, dhpcd, and custom binaries. The rule calculates a behavior score based on connection count and port usage diversity. Legitimate update services and known benign calls are excluded via pattern matching.
notes: Investigate process queuing, destination IPs/domains, and any download activity. Review users/process owners for compromise.

title: Suspicious Execution of Obfuscated or Masqueraded Linux Binaries by Root
description: Detection of potentially malicious binaries executed from typical system directories (/bin, /tmp, etc.) by root user, exhibiting masquerading or obfuscation tactics (random filenames, deleted after exec, or abnormal file operations). This is typical of post-exploitation behavior, such as EDR evasion or lateral movement tools.

mitre.description: Masquerading involves actors running code from locations or with names that look legitimate to avoid detection.

log_lines: 2025-12-04 19:04:01.338605+00:00,SL_Suspicious Execution of Obfuscated or Masqueraded Linux Binaries by Root,SL_Suspicious Execution of Obfuscated or Masqueraded Linux Binaries by Root,High,"Detects execution of suspicious or potentially malicious binaries from common Linux execution directories (/bin, /usr/bin, /lib, /usr/lib, /tmp, /var/tmp) initiated by the root user. This behavior is indicative of post-exploitation activity involving masquerading techniques, use of randomly named binaries, dropped artifacts (e.g., libudev.so.6, dhpcd), or abuse of common utilities such as mv, chmod, and scp in non-standard contexts.

2025-12-04 18:04:06.394233+00:00,SL_Suspicious Execution of Obfuscated or Masqueraded Linux Binaries by Root,SL_Suspicious Execution of Obfuscated or Masqueraded Linux Binaries by Root,High,"Detects execution of suspicious or potentially malicious binaries from common Linux execution directories (/bin, /usr/bin, /lib, /usr/lib, /tmp, /var/tmp) initiated by the root user. This behavior is indicative of post-exploitation activity involving masquerading techniques, use of randomly named binaries, dropped artifacts (e.g., libudev.so.6, dhpcd), or abuse of common utilities such as mv, chmod, and scp in non-standard contexts.
notes: Correlate with persistence events, privilege escalation attempts, and possible lateral movements. Review timeline of root user actions and filesystem changes.

title: Brute Force and Excessive Failed Logon Attempts
description: There are numerous alerts indicating repeated failed logon attempts from the same remote IP to Azure VMs or hosts, consistent with brute force activity. Student/test/lab events may be noise, but frequency and distribution indicate real threat potential.

mitre.description: Adversaries may use brute force methods such as repeated logon attempts to gain unauthorized access.

log_lines: 2025-12-04 19:33:26.523204+00:00,SEWALT Alert Rule (Brute Force Attempt Detection),SEWALT Alert Rule (Brute Force Attempt Detection),Medium,Discovers when the same remote IP address has failed to log in to the same local host 10 times or more within the last 5 hours.,ASI Scheduled Alerts

2025-12-04 19:31:32.806098+00:00,Victor Cardoso - Brute Force Attempt Detection (2025624 192517),Victor Cardoso - Brute Force Attempt Detection (2025624 192517),Medium,Sentinel Rule that will discover when the same remote IP address has failed to log in to the same local host (Azure VM) 10 times or more within the last 5 hours.,ASI Scheduled Alerts

2025-12-04 18:48:11.004477+00:00,SL_Brute Force External Network Login Attempts - GeoIP Enriched,SL_Brute Force External Network Login Attempts - GeoIP Enriched,Medium,Detects potential brute-force login attempts from external sources based on repeated failed network logons. Enriched with geo-location and known bad network tagging. Mapped to MITRE ATT&CK T1110 (Brute Force).,ASI Scheduled Alerts
notes: Enrich with source IPs and destination hosts. Review if any of the attempts succeeded, and check for correlated privilege escalation or lateral movement activity.

title: Impossible Travel/Unusual Geographical Sign-in Patterns
description: Multiple alerts for users authenticating from geographically distant locations within short time periods, indicating either use of VPN/proxies, account compromise, or credential theft.

mitre.description: Adversaries use stolen credentials to access resources. Impossible travel often signals credentials in use by an attacker from another location.

log_lines: 2025-12-04 19:21:18.630330+00:00,AnalyticsRule_JB_ImpossibleTravelAlert,AnalyticsRule_JB_ImpossibleTravelAlert,Medium,"Flags user sign-ins from locations over 15 km apart within 15 minutes, indicating potential account compromise. Query runs every 15 minutes.",ASI Scheduled Alerts

2025-12-04 18:40:42.350488+00:00,-dereckAlert Rule (Potential Impossible Travel),-dereckAlert Rule (Potential Impossible Travel),Medium,"Design a Sentinel Scheduled Query Rule within Log Analytics that will discover when a user logs in to more than a certain number of locations within a given time period; for example, trigger if a user logs into 2 different geographic regions within a 7 day time period. (ensure the appropriate logs show up before creating the alert rule)",ASI Scheduled Alerts

2025-12-04 18:29:42.831207+00:00,Potential Impossible Travel - seb,Potential Impossible Travel - seb,Medium,"Sometimes corporations have policies against working outside of designated geographic regions, account sharing (this should be standard), or use of non-corporate VPNs. The following scenario will be used to detect unusual logon behavior by creating an incident if a users login patterns are too erratic. “Too erratic” can be defined as logging in from multiple geographic regions within a given time period.
2025-12-04 18:38:28.246359+00:00,Opal - Potential Impossible Travel,Opal - Potential Impossible Travel,High,,ASI Scheduled Alerts
notes: Investigate frequency and user context. Cross-reference with MFA failures, new devices, or administrator roles.

title: PowerShell Web Requests Indicating Possible Remote Payload Download
description: Alerts triggered on execution of PowerShell commands making web requests (often via Invoke-WebRequest). This behavior is indicative of an attacker downloading payloads or tools during post-exploitation, persistence establishment, or further lateral movement.

mitre.description: Adversaries may transfer tools or payloads onto victim systems by making web requests from a command shell, often using PowerShell.

log_lines: 2025-12-04 17:51:55.932735+00:00,AshJ - Create Alert Rule (PowerShell Suspicious Web Request),AshJ - Create Alert Rule (PowerShell Suspicious Web Request),Medium,"Sometimes when a bad actor has access to a system, they will attempt to download malicious payloads or tools directly from the internet to expand their control or establish persistence. This is often achieved using legitimate system utilities like PowerShell to blend in with normal activity. By leveraging commands such as Invoke-WebRequest, they can download files or scripts from an external server and immediately execute them, bypassing traditional defenses or detection mechanisms. This tactic is a hallmark of post-exploitation activity, enabling them to deploy malware, exfiltrate data, or establish communication channels with a command-and-control (C2) server. Detecting this behavior is critical to identifying and disrupting an ongoing attack.
2025-12-04 16:57:40.816029+00:00,PowerShell Invoke-WebRequest Detected,PowerShell Invoke-WebRequest Detected,High,,ASI Scheduled Alerts
notes: Obtain URLs/domains involved and file hashes of downloaded content. Review for execution of newly downloaded files or scripts.

title: Internet Facing System Alert
description: Multiple high-severity alerts indicating systems are exposed to the internet. These represent an increased attack surface for exploitation and should be reviewed for accidental exposure or misconfigured access control.

mitre.description: Public-facing systems are a frequent target for exploitation, brute force, or reconnaissance attempts.

log_lines: 2025-12-04 19:06:08.285399+00:00,is Internet Facing Alert,is Internet Facing Alert,High,Check system that are internet facing,MDATP
2025-12-04 18:46:48.373168+00:00,is Internet Facing Alert,is Internet Facing Alert,High,Check system that are internet facing,MDATP
notes: Determine intended/authorized exposure. Review external firewall rules and recent public scans or exploits.

title: Suspicious Network Beaconing from Linux CLI Utilities (Potential C2 Activity)
description: High-fidelity detection of network beaconing originating from Linux CLI tools (curl, wget, dhpcd, etc.) was triggered. The activity was scored based on unusual connection count and diverse port usage patterns typical for command-and-control (C2) channels. Pattern matching excluded known legitimate traffic, increasing confidence in malicious intent.

mitre.description: Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols—use of legitimate network utilities to establish outbound C2 channels

log_lines: 2025-12-04 19:40:28.738772+00:00,SL[LINUX] Suspicious Network Beaconing from CLI Utilities (curl, wget, dhpcd, etc.),SL[LINUX] Suspicious Network Beaconing from CLI Utilities (curl, wget, dhpcd, etc.),High,Detects potential command-and-control (C2) activity originating from known command-line tools such as curl, wget, dhpcd, and custom binaries...
notes: This is a low-false-positive rule. Immediate incident response and network pivoting recommended.

title: Encoded PowerShell Command Detected
description: Execution of PowerShell using the -enc or -encodedcommand flags, which is indicative of TTPs for obfuscation often seen in malware or post-exploitation scripts. Known benign scripts were excluded according to the detection logic.

mitre.description: Obfuscated Files or Information: Command Obfuscation—adversaries encode commands to evade detection.

log_lines: 2025-12-04 19:29:14.657677+00:00,SL_Encoded PowerShell Command Detection,SL_Encoded PowerShell Command Detection,High,Detects use of PowerShell with -enc/-encodedcommand, excluding known benign scripts (gc_worker, ACL, Nessus).
notes: Validate process ancestry and command content. Encoded PowerShell is a strong sign of malicious activity.

title: Suspicious Execution of Obfuscated or Masqueraded Linux Binaries by Root
description: Detection of suspicious or potentially malicious binaries executed from standard Linux directories by the root user. Criteria includes masquerading techniques, random file names, deleted binaries post execution, or suspicious file operations—strong post-exploitation signal.

mitre.description: Masquerading: Masquerade Task or Service—adversaries rename executables or execute from legitimate locations to evade detection.

log_lines: 2025-12-04 19:04:01.338605+00:00,SL_Suspicious Execution of Obfuscated or Masqueraded Linux Binaries by Root,SL_Suspicious Execution of Obfuscated or Masqueraded Linux Binaries by Root,High,Detects execution of suspicious or potentially malicious binaries from common Linux execution directories (/bin, /usr/bin, /lib, /usr/lib, /tmp, /var/tmp) initiated by the root user...
notes: Review for lateral movement or persistence mechanisms; confirm if binaries are truly unauthorized.

description: Multiple impossible travel detections, flagging user sign-ins from geographic locations that are not physically possible within short time frames. This pattern strongly suggests credential theft or token/session hijacking.

mitre.description: Valid Accounts—adversaries leverage compromised credentials for unauthorized access from disparate geography

title: Suspicious Network Beaconing Indicative of Command and Control (C2) Activity via CLI Utilities
description: Behavioral analytics detected potential C2 communication from a Linux system via CLI utilities such as curl, wget, or dhcpd. The activity is flagged by a high-signal, low-noise rule designed to catch suspicious connections from command-line tools outside usual update/service patterns. This is typically associated with malware or post-exploitation tooling attempting outbound comms.

mitre.description: Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols — Adversaries use standard web protocols for C2 and data exfiltration

log_lines: 2025-12-04 19:40:28.738772+00:00,"SL[LINUX] Suspicious Network Beaconing from CLI Utilities (curl, wget, dhcpd, etc.)","SL[LINUX] Suspicious Network Beaconing from CLI Utilities (curl, wget, dhcpd, etc.)",High,Detects potential command-and-control (C2) activity originating from known command-line tools such as curl, wget, dhpcd, and custom binaries...
indicators_of_compromise: CLI utilities: curl, wget, dhcpd (process context)
notes: The alert is tuned for low false positives; post-exploitation or active malware likely. Immediate response required.

title: Encoded PowerShell Command Execution Detected
description: Execution of PowerShell with -enc or -encodedcommand flag detected, excluding known benign scripts. This TTP is frequently used by attackers to obfuscate their intentions and bypass inspection tools, and is commonly part of post-exploitation, malware delivery, or lateral movement.

mitre.description: Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell — Execution of encoded/obfuscated commands

log_lines: 2025-12-04 19:29:14.657677+00:00,SL_Encoded PowerShell Command Detection,SL_Encoded PowerShell Command Detection,High,Detects use of PowerShell with -enc/-encodedcommand, excluding known benign scripts (gc_worker, ACL, Nessus).
notes: This usually indicates active attacker activity or automation using obfuscated PowerShell.

title: Suspicious Execution of Obfuscated or Masqueraded Linux Binaries by Root
description: High-confidence detection of a root-initiated process in a Linux environment executing binaries from common system directories (e.g., /bin, /tmp) that exhibit masquerading, random/filedropped naming, or are deleted post-execution. This pattern is consistent with privilege escalation or post-exploitation, often following initial compromise.

mitre.description: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location — Adversaries may masquerade binaries post-exploitation to hide actions.

log_lines: 2025-12-04 19:04:01.338605+00:00,SL_Suspicious Execution of Obfuscated or Masqueraded Linux Binaries by Root,SL_Suspicious Execution of Obfuscated or Masqueraded Linux Binaries by Root,High,Detects execution of suspicious or potentially malicious binaries from common Linux execution directories (/bin, /usr/bin, /lib, /usr/lib, /tmp, /var/tmp) initiated by the root user...
indicators_of_compromise: Process context: root running unknown/random binaries
notes: Detects classic post-exploitation. Immediate investigation and host isolation recommended.

mitre.description: Brute Force: Password Guessing — Automated logon attempts using common/guessable credentials.

description: Multiple alerts signal user sign-ins from geographically distant locations within an implausible time window. This indicates probable account compromise, credential reuse, or use of anonymization services (VPN/proxy).

mitre.description: Valid Accounts — Adversaries may leverage compromised accounts and attempt access from locations inconsistent with user behavior.
